Set Work In Progress

Also, Michael -- since I'm currently looking into some similar modifications to fru-device (supporting alternate FRU formats, though it looks like you're a bit farther along on this than I am on mine at the moment), it'd be great if you could post your related follow-on work whenever it's available (WIP is fine of course) so I can scope it out to hopefully avoid too much conflicting/duplicated work.

And for what it's worth I've now posted a bit of what I'm working on here:
 - https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51548
 - https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51580
Haven't reviewed the full patch yet.
I don't think the style of prefixing enums/constants with `k` is used elsewhere in entity-manager (or OpenBMC AFAIK), so it looks a bit incongruous here.

I was following this(https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Enumerator_Names) to name the enum value.
But yea.. We should make it congruous, will change it.
Done

I guess the rest of the codebase is a bit inconsistent in this regard already (sometimes it's `Fru`, sometimes it's `FRU`), but personally I'd prefer to keep acronyms in identifiers upper-cased, so e.g. `kTypeDDR3` instead of `kTypeDdr3` and such (as is also already the case with the ModuleType and EccType enums below).

And likewise `s/Spd/SPD/`, `s/Ecc/ECC/`, etc. elsewhere.

This "how do you capitalize shorthand in a camel cased variable" problem been debated multiple times within the project.  I personally as a maintainer don't have a strong opinion here.  I find DDR just about as readable as Ddr, and given that we don't have a good way to lint for that kind of thing, I generally don't enforce it, but if the author wanted to make the change, I'm fine either way.
Done
`cal` seems like a slightly odd abbreviation for `calculate` to me; I'd find `calc` a lot clearer personally.
Done
Given that these are methods on the SPD class, having the `spd` prefix on them seems a bit redundant.

I added the `spd` prefix because there is a similar variable called `dimmSize`. I want to clearly distinguish between these two.
But I am OK with removing the `spd` prefix if `totalSize`/`usedSize` is not ambiguous.
I removed all the `spd` prefix on all the methods except `spdSize()` because spdSize is the spd eeprom size. I want to differentiate it from `dimmDize`
Maybe create a struct with named `year` and `week` members instead of a generic std::pair?
Done

Not knowing anything offhand about the JEDEC SPD spec, are there any guarantees about the encoding of these fields?  (e.g. are they defined as ASCII or something?)  If so, we could perhaps use a slightly more specific datatype, though a raw byte array might be the best option if the spec doesn't dictate anything in particular.
Lets use std::string here.  vector<uint8_t> is a bit hard to use in most contexts.

Part number shall be written in ASCII format while the serial number is not.
Actually in our case the serial number is not written in ASCII format.
So I think serial number should keep using `vector`.

Type of part number changed to `string`.
Both changed to std::string.

Perhaps subsequent patches that I haven't seen yet will make this clear, but what's the purpose of these methods being (pure) virtual?  I would have thought that there would basically only be one real implementation of JEDEC SPD parsing; are there going to be multiple providers/concrete subclasses for some reason?
+1.  Ideally this should be answered in your commit message.

The reason for those virtual functions is to support different generations of DIMM SPD. Because the SPD format has some differences between generations. For example `spdUsedSize` and `spdTotalSize` are the same in DDR5 while it’s two different fields in DDR4.

I also add them to commit message.
I couldn't tell you the exact parameter configuration off the top of my head, but I suspect this could probably be done via boost::crc instead of having our own open-coded version of it.
Actually, this might already be defined for us in boost.  try crc_ccitt_type

Thanks for the information.
After I tested I think `crc_xmodem_t` should be the correct one.

> //! Computation type for the actual XMODEM|ZMODEM|CRC-16/ACORN standard
> typedef crc_optimal<16, 0x1021, 0, 0, false, false>       crc_xmodem_t;
In general we prefer composition to inheritance.  Also, given the differences, it's not clear how they would expose the same API.

> In general we prefer composition to inheritance.
Some fields in SPD will change in different generations.
For example
- range expanded
- formula changed 
- fields become mandatory.
But from an external point of view they are still the same field, which is why I chose to use inheritance.

> it's not clear how they would expose the same API.
Most of the essential parameters of DIMM exist in any generation of SPD (dimm type, dimm speed, dimm size etc), these are the APIs I intend to expose in this base class.
Inheritance removed.

Your commit message should answer "why" which is a little difficult in this patchset because:
1. There's no code actually reading this from a real i2c SPD.
2. This publishes no interfaces to the greater system

So it's pretty difficult to understand how this SPD information is intended to be used, what APIs it's going to implement, ect, from how it's written.  I do appreciate you breaking this change up, but until the full series is available, it's difficult to verify that this patchset is correct.

I just submitted all the patchset to gerrit for visibility. Currently it works but has bugs in it. I am still working on it.
I will rephrase my commit log once the CLs are ready.
This is a great start`

Thanks for all the comments.
As you said, it's difficult to verify this patchset unless the entire series are avaliable.
So I will push the rest of patchset first then come back to solve the defect here.
I think this series can be completed within 2 more patches.

Feel free to stack as many patches as you need to add the feature, my only ask is that for the refactorings that you'll need to do to existing code, please put those in the front of the series so they can be merged faster than the rest of the spd support.
Got it. Then I will resolve the refactoring related comments first.

Please don't add virtualized inherited classes unless there are at least 3 users of said class.  Otherwise, it's just extra implementation complexity that is difficult to maintain.  I suspect in this case, given the very minor differences between the various spd types, a simple "type" flag that can be branched on in the 3 difference cases, using a common class would be sufficient.

> Please don't add virtualized inherited classes unless there are at least 3 users of said class.
I planned to support DDR5 for now, and might support DDR4 afterwards as well since DDR4 is now widely used.
Meanwhile, the DDR generation is also keeping updating(DDR6 is in the planning phase). I believe this virtual class can accommodate the later DDR generation. So I think the users of this virtual class will keep increasing.

> given the very minor differences between the various spd types, a simple "type" flag that can be branched on in the 3 difference cases, using a common class would be sufficient.
The differences between DDR4 and DDR5 might be minor. However I compared DDR1/2 with DDR4 and the differences are huge.
I know this comparison might not be fair since DDR1/2 is a historical product. But I want to make it as flexible as possible since the DDR generation keeps updating (at a fast speed).
Inheritance removed.

It looks like in the spd spec, these are defined as 8 bit, should this be

enum class SPDType: uint8_t
Please declare outside the class if they are reused outside the class.
Done. I also changed `ModuleType` to 8 bits. Most of the type in SPD spec are 8 bits.
Done
Considering that these enums have gaps in them, and don't have a "max" field defined, I suspect you aren't range checking these appropriately.

Right, range checking will not work. So I use enumeration checking instead.
See https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51435/8..9/src/spd.cpp#36
typo
Done
Lets avoid inventing a new "Date" type, and prefer to convert to a type we already have (std::chrono::time_point probably)

Done.
Note: `std::chrono::time_point` doesn't have `weeks of a year`.
So it needs a conversion.

Please make your enums the appropriate size, then use sizeof() for this, instead of hardcoding the number and adding a comment about why it's that way.

Also, this probably needs to be size_t, not uint32_t

> Please make your enums the appropriate size, then use sizeof() for this
I can’t do it in the current design. Because the actual DIMM struct is defined in ddr<x>.h instead of here.

> Also, this probably needs to be size_t, not uint32_t
Done.
changed to `sizeof(SPDKeyFields);`
Is there a way to avoid this race by constructing the object with its underlying structure?

Sorry for the misleading. There shouldn't have any race because `getFromImage` is the only way to create an instance of `SPD`.
So `type()` function will only be called after `getFromImage` creates an instance successfully.
There are lots of functions in this class (this one included) that aren't used.  Please make sure that any code you're writing is actually used.

Noticed.
All the functions should be call by the dbus in this CL. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/53605/1
Please create an actual struct for this, not std::pair to ensure that it's obvious to the reader what each field means (which would also remove the need for the comment on line 78)

first off, this isn't a pair (maybe the comment is old?)  Second, these kind of comments shouldn't be required if the class is properly documented.  With that said, we shouldn't be producing dates as structs like this.  We should be producing dates as std::chrono::time_point.
Changed to `std::chrono::time_point`
Static casting to an enum doesn't guarantee that the data is correct or in range.  This kind of conversion is done in several places that will need to be fixed.
I will add an inline functoin to convert `SPDType<->byte`
I used flat_map to replace the enum class so that we don't need to static_cast.
Please prefer to use explicit range checks for the things that are required.  In this case, you're indexing to zero, so you require that size > 1, not 3

Ack. Directly change to `1` will make it become another magic number.
Let me think of it.
I restructed the code. No this kind of issue anymore.
Magic numbers?

It's the range of the SPD size defined in SPD spec.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51649/17/src/ddr5.cpp#210

I didn't give these upper/lower bound a name because almost every fields have limited range. Naming all of them might not a good idea.
For example:
`busWidth` must be 0~3 https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51649/17/src/ddr5.cpp#138
`diePerPackage` must be 0~5 https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51649/17/src/ddr5.cpp#166
Done
Please recheck this.  As-written, this function returns nullptr in all cases, which I'm fairly certain is not what you intended.

It's expected. Since none of the implementation is done in this CL.
return value will be changed once a DDR<x> implementation is done.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51649/17/src/spd.cpp#49

Sorry for taking so long time to response.
I will focus on this feature from now on.
